title: An athlete uses physics to shatter world records - Asaf Bar-Yosef

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the athlete who invented the high jump technique known as the Fosbury Flop?

options.label: A
options.text: Dick Fosbury

options.label: B
options.text: John Smith

options.label: C
options.text: Michael Johnson

options.label: D
options.text: LeBron James

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept in physics that the Fosbury Flop relies on?

options.label: A
options.text: Gravity

options.label: B
options.text: Center of mass

options.label: C
options.text: Momentum

options.label: D
options.text: Velocity

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's center of mass when they lift their hands in the air?

options.label: A
options.text: It moves downwards

options.label: B
options.text: It stays the same

options.label: C
options.text: It moves upwards

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears

multiple-choice.question: Why is the Fosbury Flop more effective than traditional high jump techniques?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it requires less force to jump

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows the jumper to apply the same amount of force but raise their body higher

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is faster than traditional techniques

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is more difficult to learn

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the jumper's center of mass being below the bar in the Fosbury Flop?

options.label: A
options.text: The jumper must apply more force to lift their center of mass above the bar

options.label: B
options.text: The jumper can apply the same amount of force but raise their body higher

options.label: C
options.text: The jumper's body becomes heavier

options.label: D
options.text: The jumper's body becomes lighter

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason why the speaker spent the last five years of his life thinking about being wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the concept of self-talk and its importance in human behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: To study the phenomenon of error blindness and its impact on human decision-making.

options.label: C
options.text: To explore the idea of being wrong and how it affects human nature.

options.label: D
options.text: To examine the role of cultural influences on our perception of being wrong.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do we tend to feel uncomfortable when we are wrong about something?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it feels embarrassing and shameful.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it makes us feel like we are not in control.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it requires us to confront our own fallibility.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a sign of weakness.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "crypto theme" that Ira Glass, the host of This American Life, mentions in his conversation with the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The theme of being right and never making mistakes.

options.label: B
options.text: The theme of being wrong and making mistakes.

options.label: C
options.text: The theme of surprise and reversal in storytelling.

options.label: D
options.text: The theme of plot twists and red herrings in fiction.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between humans and other animals in terms of their capacity for error?

options.label: A
options.text: Humans are more prone to making mistakes due to their complex cognitive abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: Humans are less prone to making mistakes due to their unique brain structure.

options.label: C
options.text: Humans are obsessed with trying to figure out the world around them, which leads to errors.

options.label: D
options.text: Humans are not capable of making mistakes at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument for the importance of embracing the possibility of being wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: That it allows us to avoid mistakes and achieve perfection.

options.label: B
options.text: That it enables us to learn from our errors and improve ourselves.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is essential for creativity, productivity, and innovation.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is a sign of weakness and should be avoided at all costs.

multiple-choice.question: C: To explore the idea of being wrong and how it affects human nature.
C: Because it requires us to confront our own fallibility.
C: The theme of surprise and reversal in storytelling.
C: Humans are obsessed with trying to figure out the world around them, which leads to errors.
C: That it is essential for creativity, productivity, and innovation.
What is the reason why the element Meitnerium was named after Lisa Meitner?

options.label: A
options.text: Because she was the first woman to earn a PhD in physics in Austria.

options.label: B
options.text: Because she discovered the element Meitnerium.

options.label: C
options.text: Because she never received the Nobel Prize for her discovery of fission.

options.label: D
options.text: Because she worked with Max Planck.

multiple-choice.question: How many people were involved in naming the element Meitnerium?
What is the process of creating the element Meitnerium?

options.label: A
options.text: Combining two lighter elements to create a heavier element.

options.label: B
options.text: Separating a heavier element into two lighter elements.

options.label: C
options.text: Transmuting a lighter element into a heavier element.

options.label: D
options.text: Decomposing a heavier element into its constituent elements.

options.text: Planckium

options.label: B
options.text: Meitnerium

options.label: C
options.text: Mietnerium

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: It can detect radioactivity at a distance of 100 meters.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It can detect radioactivity in a parcel while it is being carried by the postman.

options.label: D
options.text: It can detect radioactivity in a parcel before it is delivered.

options.text: To avoid arguments about who discovered the element first.

options.label: C

title: The history of marriage - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the main purposes of marriage in sedentary agricultural societies about 10,000 years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: To secure rights to land and property by designating children born under certain circumstances as rightful heirs.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide a way for people to express their love and companionship.

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure the continuation of family lineages.

options.label: D
options.text: To appease restless spirits.

multiple-choice.question: What was the practice of Adelphopoiesis, or "brother-making," in Orthodox churches?

options.label: A
options.text: A form of polygamy where a man had multiple wives.

options.label: B
options.text: A publicly recognized same-sex union.

options.label: C
options.text: A way of making a man a part of a family by adopting him as a brother.

options.label: D
options.text: A form of ghost marriage where a deceased person was married to a living person.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the reasons why the modern idea of marriage as being mainly about love and companionship emerged in the last couple of centuries?

options.label: A
options.text: The growth of the middle class and the ability of people to support a new household on their own.

options.label: B
options.text: The decline of the extended family and the focus on individual happiness and pursuits.

options.label: C
options.text: The rise of industrialization and urbanization.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What was the practice of ghost marriage in China?

options.label: A
options.text: A way of continuing family lineages by marrying a deceased person to a living person.

options.label: B
options.text: A way of appeasing restless spirits by conducting a marriage ceremony for a deceased person.

options.label: C
options.text: A way of ensuring the continuation of family lineages by adopting a child as a deceased family member.

options.label: D
options.text: A way of providing a way for people to express their love and companionship.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the ways in which the idea of marriage changed over time as a society's structure, values, and goals changed?

options.label: A
options.text: The focus on individual happiness and pursuits led to a decrease in the number of people marrying at a later age.

options.label: B
options.text: The focus on individual happiness and pursuits led to a decrease in the number of people getting divorced.

options.label: C
options.text: The focus on individual happiness and pursuits led to a change in the way people made matches, with a greater emphasis on love and companionship.

options.label: D
options.text: The focus on individual happiness and pursuits led to a change in the way people viewed marriage, with a greater emphasis on practicality and family duty.

title: Eli the eel: A mysterious migration - James Prosek

multiple-choice.question: Where is the eel, Eli, born?

options.label: A
options.text: In the middle of the North Atlantic Ocean, about a thousand miles east of Bermuda.

options.label: B
options.text: In the Sargasso Sea, a subtropical gyre in the middle of the ocean.

options.label: C
options.text: In a freshwater stream in Europe or North America.

options.label: D
options.text: In a saltwater ocean near the coast of Europe or North America.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of food for a female eel like Elaine in freshwater?

options.label: A
options.text: Small fish and plankton.

options.label: B
options.text: Grasshoppers, crickets, small fish, insect larvae, frogs, baby birds, and almost anything she can get her mouth around.

options.label: C
options.text: Algae and aquatic plants.

options.label: D
options.text: Insects and small crustaceans.

multiple-choice.question: How do eels know when it's time to return to the ocean?

options.label: A
options.text: They can detect changes in the water temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: They can sense the presence of other eels.

options.label: C
options.text: They are attracted to the smell of saltwater.

options.label: D
options.text: They don't know exactly how they know, but something calls to them.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a female eel like Elaine as she undergoes a metamorphosis before returning to the ocean?

options.label: A
options.text: Her skin gets thinner, and her fins get smaller.

options.label: B
options.text: Her eyes enlarge by about ten times, her skin gets thicker, and her fins get larger.

options.label: C
options.text: Her body becomes more streamlined, and her tail gets longer.

options.label: D
options.text: Her scales become more colorful, and her fins get more prominent.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated length of a female eel like Elaine as an adult?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 2 feet long and weighing up to 5 pounds.

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 4 feet long and weighing up to 13 pounds.

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 6 feet long and weighing up to 20 pounds.
